awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project:  Increasing STEM Degree Production through Undergraduate Research and Collaborations
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in STEM and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The award to Harris Stowe State University seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines, including STEM Teacher Education. The institution seeks to provide students with the academic preparation, as well as analytical and technical competencies they will need to succeed in graduate school or STEM careers. 

The project has three specific objectives that tie in to the overarching goal: 1) to increase the recruitment and enrollment of first-year and transfer STEM majors; 2) to increase the retention and graduation of STEM majors; and 3) to increase student engagement through faculty development opportunities. A set of evidence-based strategies and interventions has been designed to achieve these objectives. Through the evaluation plan the project will address the question: "To what extent can academic and social integration interventions impact student retention, student success, student engagement and graduation in STEM disciplines, particularly at a small Historically Black University?"
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Contributing to the national agenda to increase the number of underrepresented minority STEM graduates and broaden participation in STEM fields, Harris-Stowe State University (HSSU), in August 2014, secured a National Science Foundation HBCU-UP Implementation grant to launch a university project titled Increasing STEM Degree Production through Undergraduate Research and Collaborations. Resulting from the grant, HSSU grew its STEM academic enterprise establishing a Sustainability & Urban Ecology degree. Additionally, HSSU?s increased STEM enrollment by 21% and directly serviced 50% of HSSU?s first-time full-time (FTFT) STEM freshman and 50% of STEM Transfer students during the project. First and second year retention rates and second and third year persistence rates were significantly higher for students who participated in the project than students who did not participate. Transfer student participants were retained and persisted at higher rates than transfers who did not participate.

Regarding degree production, 11% (19 FTFT) of students graduated with an average time-to-degree being 4.5 years and 30 % (23 Transfers) graduated with an average time-to-degree being 2.9 years. STEM degree production saw a significant increase during the project, yet there is more to be done at HSSU for continuous improvement. STEM advanced at HSSU as a result of the project.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2021
Modified by: Freddie E Wills
